greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Generalized Pascal triangle read by rows: add the four terms that are right above you, three rows back.
comment: To explain the rule of formation, consider the first few rows of the triangle, which are:
The left and right edge are all 1's, the entries outside the triangle are all 0's, and the first 3 rows are all 1's.
Thereafter each term E (say) is the sum of the 4 terms A, B, C, D exactly above it three rows back.
Adding the two entries just above you in the previous row gives Pascal's triangle, A007318. Adding the three entries just above you two rows back gives A169623.
link: Robert Israel, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..10010 (rows 0 to 141, flattened)
formula: T(n,0)=T(n,n)=1, T(n,k)=0 if k<0 or k>n, also T(2,1)=1; thereafter T(n,k) = T(n-3,k-3) + T(n-3,k-2) + T(n-3,k-1) + T(n-3,k).
maple: elif n >= 0 and k = n then 1
for n from 0 to 14 do lprint([seq(T(n,k),k=0..n)]); od:
results.author: _N. J. A. Sloane_, Nov 23 2017
